title: About
text:
Maggie Moss is a Geosciences PhD student at Colorado State University studying the geochemistry and petrology of the Yellowstone Plateau Volcanic Field’s basaltic magma system. Moss holds a Master of Urban Planning degree from New York University, where she focused on natural hazards and city planning. Her background in petrography, field geology, and physical volcanology began as an undergraduate at George Washington University, where she received a Luther Rice Fellowship to study silicic volcanism associated with Yellowstone’s third caldera cycle.
Moss recently received the Jack Kleinman Memorial Foundation grant to support her fieldwork, as well as funding from the Colorado Scientific Society to launch an undergraduate mentorship program that has engaged six high-achieving students in summer fieldwork and four in ongoing laboratory research. She also leads an interdisciplinary team synthesizing geochemical and geophysical data to develop a conceptual model of the magmatic plumbing system at Akutan, one of the USGS’s very high-threat volcanoes.
In the first year of her Ph.D., Moss successfully planned and executed a month of fieldwork in Yellowstone National Park, mapping and sampling the Junction Butte basalt, Undine Falls basalt, and the basalt of the Narrows. In her first semester, she obtained an NPS research permit, trained six undergraduate and four graduate students as field assistants, and collaborated with the Yellowstone Park Archeologist to document Indigenous obsidian artifacts in her study areas.

title: Research
text:
(1) Petrologic and Geophysical Synthesis of the Magmatic System at Akutan Volcano
Moss, M., Myers, M., Mark, H., Yang, X., Cheng, Y., Gapenthin, R., Lizik, Y., Portner, D., Lee, D., Wu, S., Larsen, J., Coombs, M., Petrologic and Geophysical Synthesis of the Magmatic System at Akutan Volcano. AGU Fall Meeting, New Orleans, LA, December 2025. (First Author, Presenting) 
Abstract:
The integration of geophysical and petrological datasets remains a grand challenge in understanding the magmatic structures feeding volcanic systems. The multidisciplinary observations required to characterize a volcanic system span a wide range of temporal and spatial scales. Devising a holistic model for magmatic structures and processes requires placing these disparate pieces into a unified framework. Here we synthesize and reanalyze existing petrological and geophysical constraints for the magmatic system at Akutan, an active stratocone in the eastern Aleutian arc. Akutan has exhibited surface deformation continually since its first geodetic observations in the 1990s and produced significant seismic swarms between 1996 and 2010, with 26 known eruptions between 1900 and 1992. The results of reanalyzing seismic, geodetic, petrologic, and other data produce a coherent conceptual model of Akutan’s magma storage and transport processes, which is defined by: (1) A partial-melt body at 8-10 kmbsl, indicated by 1D velocity models, seismic tomography, seismicity, whole rock geochemical trends, melt-inclusion volatile contents, and magnetotelluric studies. This is also consistent with median pressures using pyroxene-only barometry. Conduit branches from the body to 0-5 km depth are also indicated.  (2) Island-wide pulses of centimeter-level geodetic deformation, deep, long-period earthquakes occurring beneath the storage depth, and hot erupted magmas that indicate frequent inputs from the deeper crust. Akutan stands as an example of a well-studied system where independent constraints converge on a consistent model for the underlying magmatic structure. Such convergence may not necessarily be observed at other Aleutian volcanoes. This work for Akutan builds on the NSF-PREEVENTS synthesis efforts at 5 other Aleutian volcanoes, offering a framework for integrating multidisciplinary observations to infer conceptual models for magmatic systems at active volcanoes. 

Figure 1. Mogi source modelling result of surface inflation events at Akutan volcano over time. Black boxes show locations of inferred magma pulses. Red stars show location of long-period seismic events that may indicate movement of fluids from deeper magmatic sources.
Figure 2. Animation showing magma dynamics of Akutan volcano between 1992 (last confirmed eruption) and 2024. This figure synthesizes seismic, geodetic, petrologic, and geochemical data to create the first unified model of the volcano’s magmatic system.


(2) Colorado Paleomaps - Denver Museum of Nature & Science Collaboration


Map of Colorado showing rock types by mapped area. The SGMC database provides the foundation for the paleomapping project carried out by the Denver Museum.


(3) Dissertation: Igneous petrology, geochemistry and geochronology of basaltic plumbing systems through time at the Yellowstone Plateau Volcanic Field


(4) Field Guide to the Cascades Magmatic Arc (Forthcoming textbook in partnership with Dr. Richard Tollo, Elsevier publishing)

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching Philosophy

​Engage students through immersive, field-centered instruction to convey geologic concepts using real-world examples drawn from active volcanic systems
Foster an inclusive learning environment that encourages curiosity, collaboration, and critical observation.
Design and implement interactive learning experiences, including small-group problem solving, student-led discussions, and hands-on field activities, that emphasize hypothesis development, data interpretation, and peer-to-peer teaching.
Equip students with practical Earth science problem-solving skills by integrating field observations, laboratory analyses, and group-based projects.
Strengthen students’ ability to work effectively in teams and to recognize the relevance of geologic processes in both natural landscapes and societal contexts.
Mentor and inspire students to pursue continued engagement with geology by modeling professional scientific practice, stewardship of public lands, and pathways toward advanced study and geoscience careers.


The field team in Yellowstone National Park, navigating a backcountry traverse on-trail (Backcountry Permit 0720417254-1; Scientific Permit #8370). All research in Yellowstone must be sanctioned by a scientific permit issued through the National Park Service.


Experience
Graduate Teaching Assistant 
Colorado State University | January 2025 – Present | Fort Collins, CO 

In collaboration with faculty, creates laboratory curriculum for undergraduate geology courses, gives weekly laboratory lectures in support of main lecture topics, and grades lab assignments and final exams.  
Igneous & Metamorphic Petrology (GEOL 364), Introductory Geology Laboratory (GEOL 121), Earth and Climate Change Through Time (GEOL 154)

Program Lead, Undergraduate Geoscience Mentorship Program
Colorado State University | March 2025 – Present | Fort Collins, CO

Founded and lead a tiered undergraduate mentorship program centered on field-based research and professional development in volcanology and geochemistry.
Designed the program to provide sustained, hands-on training through mentored fieldwork in Yellowstone National Park, laboratory research, and collaborative data analysis.
Recruited, trained, and supervised undergraduate students in geologic mapping, sampling strategies, field safety, and scientific stewardship on public lands.
Continued mentorship beyond the field season through structured laboratory involvement, research skill development, and guidance on graduate school preparation, conference presentations, and scientific writing.


Graduate Teaching Assistant 
New York University | Aug 2020 – May 2021 & Jan 2022 - May 2022 | New York, NY  

Taught statistical and data analytics laboratory course to NYU graduate students on topics such as housing finance, zoning, and transportation.  
Supported NYU Wagner faculty with curriculum research, online content creation for events, and other administrative projects to enhance the school’s profile and provide support to admitted students.  

Undergraduate Teaching Assistant 
George Washington University | Aug 2017 - Dec 2018 | Washington, D.C. 

In collaboration with tenured faculty, created laboratory curriculum for undergraduate introductory geology courses, gave weekly laboratory lectures in support of main lecture topics, and graded lab assignments and final exams.  
Served as laboratory learning support for undergraduate students in Mineralogy and Igneous & Metamorphic Petrology courses, and assisted professors with grading lab assignments.

2025, Research Associate, Denver Museum of Nature & Science
2024-Present, Volunteer, Charis Youth Ranch
2018-2021, Program Director, Out for Undergrad

title: Maggie Moss
text:
News & Updates
Moss will present an abstract of her research, Petrologic and Geophysical Synthesis of the Magmatic System at Akutan Volcano, at the American Geophysical Union Annual Meeting on 12/18
Moss will present with Dr. Xiaotao Yang on Akutan Volcano at the SZ4D-supported workshop “Research Prioritization in the Alaska-Aleutian Arc” on 12/14
Moss won the 2025-2026 Jack Kleinman Memorial Grant for Volcanology to support her field work in Yellowstone National Park

title: Curiculum Vitae
text:
Maggie Moss | maggie.moss@colostate.edu | Fort Collins, CO 
Professional Summary 
Volcanology, Geochemistry, & Petrology PhD Candidate with four years of experience in academic research, writing, and data analysis. Strong research background in petrological and geochemical disciplines, as well as ample experience in planning and conducting fieldwork in volcanic environments. Aspiring to leverage skills to conduct petrological and geochemical research on the Yellowstone Plateau Volcanic Field basaltic plumbing system.
